polysolve package

Submodules

polysolve.solver module

polysolve.solver.cubic(a, b, c, d)

Solves the roots of a cubic equation.

Uses the cubic formula. Result must be complex.

Parameters:

  • a (float) – \(x^3\) coefficient.

  • b (float) – \(x^2\) coefficient.

  • c (float) – \(x\) coefficient.

  • d (float) – Constant value.

Returns:

Positive and negative roots of cubic.

Return type:

tuple[complex, complex, complex]

polysolve.solver.quadratic(a, b, c)

Solves the roots of a quadratic equation.

Uses the quadratic formula. Result must be real.

Parameters:

  • a (float) – \(x^2\) coefficient.

  • b (float) – \(x\) coefficient.

  • c (float) – Constant value.

Returns:

Positive and negative roots of quadratic.

Return type:

tuple[float, float]

Raises:

ValueError – Discriminant < 0 implying imaginary root.

Notes

Equation of the form:

\[ax^{2} + bx + c\]

Examples

>>> quadratic(1, 2, 0)
(0.0, -2.0)
>>> quadratic(3., 0., -1.)
(0.5773502691896257, -0.5773502691896257)

See also

numpy.polyval

Evaluate polynomial at point.

References

[1]

O. McNoleg, “The integration of GIS, remote sensing, expert systems …
